entry.title: Enable Joule to Pass Requests to Microsoft Copilot and Teams
entry.content:
This blog shows you how to integrate Microsoft Copilot and Teams with Joule so that your users can have conversational interactions that include content about integrated Microsoft applications. With the previous blog, we established the technical infrastructure so that Microsoft and SAP systems trust each other and exchange any required tokens for the two systems to interact. In the next steps, we add the required API permissions for Microsoft Graph.

The following figure shows our target architecture.

Prerequisites

  • You've configured your tenants SAP Cloud Identity Services and Microsoft Entra ID to trust each other. 
    You need the TenantId which you noted down during the registration of your federation app in Microsoft Entra ID.
  • You've set up conditional authentication for Joule.

For details, see our previous blog Configuring SAP Cloud Identity Services and Microsoft Entra ID for Joule.

Configure Your Microsoft Entra ID Tenant

Go to the Entra ID Admin Center with the admin user role.

Configure API Permissions

  1. Go to Home > Identity > Applications > App registrations.
  2. Choose your federation app.
  3. Choose API permissions.
  4. Choose Add a permission.
  5. Choose Microsoft Graph.
  6. Add the following permissions:
    • Sites.Read.All
    • Mail.Read
    • People.Read.All
    • OnlineMeetingTranscript.Read.All
    • Chat.Read
    • ChannelMessage.Read.All
    • ExternalItem.Read.All
  7. Choose Add Permissions.
  8. Choose Grant Admin Consent {Entra_ID_Tenant_Name} and chooseYes.

    Give it a Go

    If everything is configured correctly, you can open your Joule client and ask, "What is in my calendar today?" Joule should check with Copilot and return your calendar information from Microsoft Outlook (assuming you use Microsoft Outlook). If Joule doesn't answer, you might have made a mistake in following these blogs or we may have a bug to iron out. Go carefully through this setup and make sure you have it right. If you are still having trouble, our support team will be happy to help you. Use support component CLT-COP.

    Conclusion

    Your landscape is configured to pass on conversations started in a Joule application in Microsoft Copilot and Teams to a Joule agent, which in turn queries further Joule agents integrated with the landscape.

entry.title: Fixing the ‚ÄúMore Members Available‚Äù Issue in SAP Analysis for Office based on Custom CDS Views
entry.content:
While working with SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics and SAP Analysis for Office (AFO), you may encounter the message: "More Members Available"

This typically appears when filtering or selecting values in prompts, and it indicates that the number of available members exceeds the display threshold. Although SAP provides a configuration setting (FetchMemberLimit) to increase the limit, this doesn‚Äôt always resolve the issue, especially when the value help includes duplicate entries.

Standard Fix: You can try increasing the member limit in AFO:

Go to File > Analysis > Customize Analysis > Technical Configuration
Set FetchMemberLimit to a value higher than the expected number of members.

However, this only works if the number of members is within the new threshold. If duplicate entries exist, the system still struggles to display all entries. In many cases, the issue arises from repeated members in the value help CDS view. This is common when the value help is generated from a custom CDS view without ensuring uniqueness.

To resolve this, modify your value help CDS view to return distinct values.

Syntax

define view XXXXX as select distinct from XXXX
{

}

In previous blogs, we have seen how value help can be generated with help of below annotations.

@Consumption.filter.multipleSelections: true
@Consumption.valueHelp:


Conclusion
The ‚ÄúMore Members Available‚Äù issue in SAP Analysis for Office can be frustrating, but it‚Äôs often solvable with a simple tweak to your CDS view design. By ensuring your value help view returns distinct values, you can improve usability and performance in your embedded analytics reports.

entry.title: Developing cloud-ready Adobe Forms on-premise
entry.content:
Hi all,

we're running S/4 HANA 2023 FP1 on-premise and as part of our clean core strategy, we need to deal with forms as well. As today, we use all available technologies like SAPScript, SmartForms as well as Adobe Forms. For sure, we only stick to Adobe Forms for new forms since several years.

To my understanding, we can use SAP Forms in BTP also on-premise. It will only be a replacement for our on-prem ADS, but there is no need to change any print report or form. So we can still use all the NAST and other stuff available since decades. This only covers infrastructure in my opinion. But what is the difference from a developers perspective?

As we all know, reports are not clean core compliant. This must also be true to print reports you define in customizing. So there will be no print report in future anymore. We actually have no plans to move to cloud but at least I want to be prepared for this. This brings me to my final question

What do we need to consider when it comes to developing SAP Forms in a cloud-ready manner? Where and how should we place our custom logic for custom forms as well as for SAP standard forms (i.e. handling templates for invoices, purchase orders etc.)? How to do this to be able to use the form in both, on-premise as well as cloud?

- do we need to replace the logic from Z-print reports to Z-classes? (we typically do this these days)
- do we need to place custom logic into interface of a form (we do this for standard forms [invoices] to be able to stick to standard print reports)
- anything else we should consider on-premise?

As said, actually there are no plans to move but at least we should be prepared for this. At least we need to refine our development guidelines to reflect any new concept.

Our current approach looks like this:
- in case of totally custom form, any code is handled by dedicated print classes. The classes implement the business logic as well as calling the form FMs
- in case of adopting standard forms, we copy standard form interfaces and add any additional custom code inside this. Same is true for form itself for sure. By this, we can still use standard print reports 
- in any case, we try to avoid mixing both concepts. Code should be either in dedicated print class or in interface but not in both.

I hope someone can give me some hints

Patrick

entry.title: Re: How to call REORG_GENERATE with algorithm ID 14 (Chec...
entry.content:
Hi Philipp,

Indeed, there is limited information about these three additional options. My understanding is as follows, just for your information:

- LEAVE_UNCHANGED_UNTOUCHED: The tables and partitions that are already correctly placed according to the table placement rules are left unchanged.
- KEEP_VALID: I don't know the difference from LEAVE_UNCHANGED_UNTOUCHED.
- NO_SPLIT: Don't perform splitting of tables or partitions during the reorganization process.

I think in most cases, LEAVE_UNCHANGED_UNTOUCHED should be good.

Regarding the command:
> CALL REORG_GENERATE(14, 'LEAVE_UNCHANGED_UNTOUCHED');
It should be correct, as I was able to execute it successfully in my local system.

>And where would I find the results of the checks?
You can find the details via the following SQL:
SELECT * FROM REORG_PLAN_INFOS;

Best regards,
Charles

entry.title: Re: Planned vs Unplanned Depreciation Behavior after Post...
entry.content:
Hi @archana_raut38 

Thank you for your question.

As you mentioned, what you observed is a standard system behaviour in public cloud. Depreciation keys like LINS do not allow switching to manual mode for unplanned postings. Once you post unplanned depreciation with a manual key, you cannot revert back without inconsistencies.

Therefore, posting extraordinary depreciations using the standard transactions type (e.g., 640) while keeping the asset assigned to the planned depreciation key remains the supported approach. After this posting, the system reduces the net book value and automatically recalculated planned depreciation across the remaining useful life. In doing so, the system ensures that:

  • Extraordinary depreciation is recognised immediately.
  • Planned depreciation continues automatically and distributed across the updated net book value and useful life.

The conclusion is you do not need to change depreciation keys. You only need to use the correct transaction type for unplanned depreciation within the standard depreciation framework.

Have a look at Extraordinary Depreciation & Depreciation Keys for more details.

Best regards

Chris

entry.content:
The recommended approach in Public Cloud is to use OData or SOAP APIs for Product Master (Material Master) creation and updates. You can build a lightweight interface that only passes the 4‚Äì5 fields your customer cares about, while default values for mandatory fields are handled in:

  • Business Configuration (SSCUI settings)
  • Defaulting logic in APIs
  • Custom Business Add‚ÄëIns (BAdIs) in the Cloud (limited but available).

Example: API_PRODUCT_SRV (OData) or Product Master ‚Äì Create/Update SOAP API.

entry.title: Solman Production Build - onprem to Azure migration approaval with dual stack
entry.content:
Hi SAP,

We are planning the migration of our on-premise Solution Manager system (dual-stack: ABAP + JAVA) to Microsoft Azure, and would like your input on the best migration approach considering the following setup:

The system is dual-stack, with ABAP and JAVA sharing a single database instance.
On-prem backups are currently stored on NetApp, while the Azure environment will use Backint for HANA backups.

We have a few specific queries:

Migration Strategy:
What is the recommended migration method for such a dual-stack setup?

Should we consider replication, backup/restore, or a hybrid approach?
How does replication work when both ABAP and JAVA share the same DB? Are there any special considerations?


Backup History Concerns:
In our DEV system, we used: DB restore for ABAP and SWPM export/import for JAVA
However, we noticed that the backup history was lost post-migration.


If we use only DB restore (without replication), will the backup catalog/history be retained?
What is the recommended approach for PROD systems to ensure backup continuity and catalog integrity?

Backup Integration:

Are there any steps needed to ensure smooth transition from NetApp-based backups to Backint on Azure?
Will the existing backup catalog be usable post-migration, or does it require reinitialization?

We‚Äôd appreciate your guidance on the most robust and supportable approach for this migration, especially considering the dual-stack nature and backup history implications.

Thanks & Regards


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Solman Production Build - onprem to Azure migration a...
entry.content:
Dear customer,

Please refer to the answers below for your questions.

What is the recommended migration method for such a dual-stack setup?

  • The recommended and the supported methods with SWPM can be found in the system copy guide: System Copy Guides - Software Provisioning Manager 1.0
  • On the target side, for Java you can choose the backup restore option, but choose that the Database is restored.
  • With normal restore it won't work without SWPM tool, and the Java instance will not start.
  • The Database instance installation is required with the Java instance.

Q: Should we consider replication, backup/restore, or a hybrid approach?
How does replication work when both ABAP and JAVA share the same DB? Are there any special considerations?
=>
A: You can use the system replication for the purpose of system copy.
Please refer to the section '5. Can SAP HANA system replication be used for system copies?' in KBA 1999880 - FAQ:HANA System Replication, and KBA 2472478. https://me.sap.com/notes/2706322
2472478 - How to copy and move tenant databases between SAP HANA systems https://me.sap.com/notes/2472478

There's no hybrid approach which is available for system copy.
 
Q: Backup History Concerns:
In our DEV system, we used: DB restore for ABAP and SWPM export/import for JAVA
However, we noticed that the backup history was lost post-migration.
If we use only DB restore (without replication), will the backup catalog/history be retained?
What is the recommended approach for PROD systems to ensure backup continuity and catalog integrity?
=>
A: If you use backup and restore method, the restore will be using the backup catalog from the backup which was taken from the source system.
Of course, the backup history will be available after the restore.

Regarding tto system copy using backup and recovery, please refer to the following documents.

Copying a Database Using Backup and Recovery 
Copying a Database Using Backup and Recovery(HANA Cockpit) 

Backup Integration:
Are there any steps needed to ensure smooth transition from NetApp-based backups to Backint on Azure?
Will the existing backup catalog be usable post-migration, or does it require reinitialization?
=>
A: Please contact the backint vendor for this question.
You may also refer to KBA 2031547 - Overview of SAP-certified 3rd party backup tools and associated support process.

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: preference indicator not set in VBAP and VBRP SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Hello all,

first time posting here, do not know if I have done everything correctly.

We encountered an issue with our preference indicator in VBAP and VBRP in SAP S/4HANA. In our coding we use SAP standard functions to determine whether preference indicator should be set or not. These standard functions (example /SAPSLL/SD0A_PREF_IND_DET) use variable gc_true and gc_false, as well as lv_active type xfeld. These variables are hard-coded to X (gc_true) or empty (gc_false).

Our issue lies in a change of the data element and domain of field PREFE in VBAP and VBRP. In our ECC environment the field PREFE has the data element PREAV which has the domain XFELD (values X and empty). Now, in our S/4 environment the same field has the data element PREFE with the domain PREFE. The domain PREFE has alphabetical values. We checked the table versions and saw that it was changed on 21.01.25 from SAP.

Are we missing something? Do we maybe need to implement a SAP Note? How can we resolve this issue?

entry.title: Re: Does Assigning a Contract to a Purchase Requisition T...
entry.content:
Yes, SAP can automatically trigger a re-release of a Purchase Requisition (PR) when you assign a contract (outline agreement) to it. This is because the system treats the assignment of a contract as a change to a release-relevant field. In standard SAP, the release strategy is based on classification (document type, account assignment, material group, source of supply, etc.). If any of these fields change, the release status is reset.

Why it is happening is because when you assign a contract to a PR, the system updates the source of supply information (e.g., contract number, item, vendor). The field Source of Supply (EBAN-KONNR, EBAN-KTPNR, EBAN-LIFNR) is release-relevant by default in many standard configurations. As soon as a release-relevant field changes, SAP cancels the existing approval and requires a new release ‚Äî this is by design, to ensure approvers validate the new sourcing decision.

You control this behavior in SPRO ‚Üí Materials Management ‚Üí Purchasing ‚Üí Purchase Requisition ‚Üí Release Procedure ‚Üí Define Release Procedure for Purchase Requisitions.

SAP Help Portal ‚Äì Manage Workflows for Purchase Requisitions - This is the official SAP Help documentation for configuring workflows and approvals in S/4HANA. It covers item-level vs. overall release, start conditions, and how changes in requisition data affect approval.

SAP Learning Hub ‚Äì Processing Release Procedures for Purchase Requisitions - This guide explains how release strategies work, why documents get blocked/unblocked, and how changes to release-relevant fields (like assigning a contract) can trigger a re-release.

entry.title: Re: Ledger EX defined in CoCd SE02 is not active in chart...
entry.content:
Go to SPRO ‚Üí Financial Accounting (New) ‚Üí Financial Accounting Global Settings (New) ‚Üí Ledgers ‚Üí Ledger ‚Üí Define and Activate Non‚ÄëLeading Ledgers. Here you see which ledgers are defined and which company codes they are active for. You can deactivate a non‚Äëleading ledger for a company code if no postings exist.

For Asset Accounting, each ledger must be active in the chart of depreciation if you want to post asset values. If your ledger (e.g., EX) is not active in the chart of depreciation, it cannot be used for asset postings ‚Äî which is why you‚Äôre seeing the inconsistency.

Check SAP note 891144 which confirm that removal requires SAP consulting support, because it involves data deletion or system reset. If no postings exist, you can safely unassign the ledger from the company code in the customizing step above.

entry.title: Our Agenda is Finalized ‚Äì How About Yours?
entry.content:
As we rapidly close in on this year‚Äôs SAP ALM Summit EMEA 2025 in Darmstadt, Germany, all preparations are now done and dusted, the agenda is set, and the event app is already alive and kicking.

If you haven‚Äôt yet registered, this is your last chance to join our annual event. If you‚Äôve already signed up, as you probably know from previous years, it‚Äôs now time to build your agenda, so head over to the web app to call up the agenda, view speaker details, and build your own personalized schedule.

As the event is in a new location this year, make sure you take a look at the floor plans and onsite guide in the app to familiarize yourself before arrival. And speaking of arrival, note that there will also be a Welcome Reception on Monday October 20, the evening before the event itself, where you can already check in and network with fellow community members and experts. But that‚Äôs literally just the start‚Ä¶

Something new for this year?

We take feedback from our ALM family seriously, so this year we will be offering hands-on workshop sessions and a Usability Test station in parallel to the regular sessions. This is your chance to learn how to build a PoC for manual testing for instance, and to test key aspects yourself ‚Äì helping to shape the future of SAP Cloud ALM for years to come. Proof that you don‚Äôt need to be an ‚Äúinfluencer‚Äù to be an influencer.

Nevertheless, if you do want to showcase your skills and expertise to a bigger audience however, what better way than by securing yourself a Solution Transformation Consultant Badge, which visitors once again have the chance of obtaining on Day 3.

It‚Äôs not a sprint, it‚Äôs an ALM-athon.

‚Ä¶although we‚Äôre 100% sure countless dev sprints have gone into the amazing ideas that will be showcased by our awesome SAP Partners and finalists during the ALM-athon. This infamous and eagerly-awaited summit showpiece has become a true highlight. Animal, witch, or indeed any other type of costume may not be mandatory per se but, as we saw last year, not only do they add to the fun and magic, they sure do put a huge smile on everyone‚Äôs faces. Last year saw Pinky and The Brain (aka NTT Data) walk away as worthy winners with their wannabe-world-dominating ‚ÄúALM Navigator‚Äù, so who knows what awaits us this year in what will be the 5th edition of the contest. Without doubt a highlight not to be missed ‚Äì but if you did miss it last year, why not get in the mood for this October by watching last year‚Äôs replay.

The six ALM-athon 2024 finalists strutting their stuff on stage ‚Äì each one a winner in our eyes

Our new venue at the Darmstadtium this year is fantastic, and we hope our agenda sessions are right on point. Don‚Äôt miss this last chance to register, sign up today to join us and other industry aficionados at the SAP ALM Summit EMEA 2025 in Darmstadt (Oct 21-23).

Feel free to share this within your community network and get involved. Huge thanks as always for reading, caring, and being such a valuable part of the ALM community. We love having you all on board and can‚Äôt wait to see you in just a few weeks!

entry.title: SAP Desktop Agent starts and disappears during automation

entry.title: Full-Page Fit vs. Scrollable Dashboards in SAC which one is better?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I'd like to discuss a common dilemma developers face when it comes to designing a dashboard in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC).
Should I design the dashboard such that it fits entirely within the browser window (Full-Page Fit)? or should I design the dashboard such that it has a scroll? Would the customer be okay with having to scroll up and down to see the contents of the dashboard? üôÑ

So, the design process begins even before we decide to click Create Story.
To Tackle this problem, I will be elaborating both the scenarios for you to make an informed decision while designing your next dashboard.

Difference between both the Dashboard Fit:

Assuming we are seeing the dashboard in a normal sized laptop screen [1366 x 768px] not a 1080p HD one. A Full-Page Fit Dashboard ensures all content is visible without scrolling, while a Scrollable Dashboard allows content to extend vertically or horizontally beyond the initial view, requiring user interaction to access additional information.

This choice significantly impacts user experience and performance. Both has its own advantages and disadvantages. Let's dive deep to understand the pros and cons of each type. 

Full-Page Fit Dashboard: (Everything visible in a single glance)

 Here in the above screenshot, see how all the KPIs presented within a single screen and there is no scroll to the right and bottom of the dashboards. This means that it is well within the boundaries of our 1366 x 768 px canvas.

Advantages

  • All KPIs are visible at a single glance, enabling quick decision-making.
  • No need to scroll, which is ideal for users who prefer a single-screen overview.

Disadvantages

  • Each KPI has less room, potentially less real estate and more congestion.
  • All widgets are triggered simultaneously, sending backend requests that can strain system resources.
  • Heavy widgets like tables may take longer to load, making the dashboard appear sluggish.

Performance Statistics

All the KPIs visible in viewport have triggered a backend request and rendered.

It's like going to a restaurant and saying bring me everything you have, even when you know you won't be able to eat everything they bring. Wasteful.üëé

Total render time ~9.5s 

All the visible KPIs have triggered a backend request and are rendered at Frontend.

Dashboard with Scroll (You gotta scroll to see what you want)

 Scroll Section 1Scroll Section 2

Here in the above screenshot, see how we have a scroll to the right of the dashboard. This means that the KPIs are spaced out more and exceeds the page's default height of 768px, therefore the user would get a scroll when accessing the dashboard.

Advantages

  • More space per KPI allows for better viewability and detailed insights.
  • SAC‚Äôs viewport loading ensures only visible widgets are triggered, reducing initial load time and backend traffic.
  • Less frequently used or heavier components can be placed lower on the page.

Disadvantages

  • Users may miss the overall picture and need to scroll to compare KPIs.
  • Scrolling back and forth can hinder quick analysis and decision-making.

Performance Statistics

All the KPIs that has been viewed initially have triggered a backend request and rendered. The Un scrolled portion doesn't trigger any backend request neither doesn't render until we preview it.

This is like going to the restaurant and placing an order and post eating the main course you get to decide if you want to take on dessert. Only what is required is being consumed here. Resourceful üëç

Total render time ~8s

 Only KPIs visible during initial preview has been rendered

Finding the Middle Ground: Tab Strips

To balance usability and performance, developers can use Tab Strip.

These are container widgets used within a SAC story to organize content into separate, switchable tabs. They allow users to view different components, such as charts or tables, within a single application by providing a navigation area to select and display the content of each tab.

Tab strip - summary sectionTab strip - Table section

Here in the above screenshot, see how the dashboard is still fitted within the canvas and also having the benefits of loading what is required.

As we have also bifurcated the components into summary and table section. The heavier/Less frequently viewed KPIs are places in the subsequent tab strips, therefore reducing the initial load.

Benefits of Tab Strips

  • Essential KPIs are displayed upfront, while heavier or less frequently accessed components (e.g., raw data tables) are placed in separate tabs.
  • SAC‚Äôs default viewport loading ensures only visible components are triggered, reducing backend load and improving responsiveness.
  • Tabs offer a cleaner and better UI/UX.

Performance Statistics

Only the Default tab strip KPIs have triggered a backend request and has been rendered. The heavier KPIs which hasn't been previewed is still untriggered and unrendered.
Total render time ~7.5s

Only the Default tab strip KPIs have triggered a backend request and has been rendered

Key Principle: "What You See Is What Loads"

SAC's viewport optimization means that only the visible components are loaded initially. This explains why Full-Page Fit dashboards can be performance intensive as everything is triggered at once. In contrast, scrollable dashboards and tab-based layouts defer loading of non-visible components, enhancing performance.

However, it‚Äôs important to note that once a user navigates to hidden sections or tabs, those components will be triggered, potentially causing a brief delay.

Final Take away

The choice between a Full-Page Fit and a Scrollable Dashboard should be guided by user requirements and usage patterns. Developers must engage with users' early phases in the design process to understand:

  • Which KPIs are most frequently accessed?
  • Is a single-screen overview preferred?
  • Are users comfortable with scrolling or tab navigation?

I hope this article was helpful. Which one do you prefer? Let me know your doubts and opinions in the comments below!

References:

Using the Loading Optimization Setting on a Story Level

entry.title: Goodbye Vibe-Coding: The Future of SAP Development with AI + Low-Code
entry.content:
Tachyonix Architecture and AI Interaction

First, I would like to thank everyone who interacted with my previous post about AI, low-code platforms, and SAPUI5. As many asked for more details, this article dives deeper into Tachyonix‚Äôs architecture and how it interacts with LLM and Noam, our AI assistant.

The Challenge We Wanted to Solve

From the beginning, our goal was clear: to create a technology that could fully leverage the power of LLMs without turning the developer into a hostage of code that is hard to maintain.

Generating raw SAPUI5 code (the so-called vibe-coding) may look attractive in the short term, but it quickly becomes a problem for evolution, support, and security.

That is why we decided to integrate artificial intelligence not into the code itself, but into the specification and automation process inside a low-code platform. This design allowed us to radically accelerate the development of SAP applications while preserving the simplicity and control that ABAP developers demand.

How AI Also Helps the ABAP Developer

Builder, Application, and Extended Vocabulary

The Tachyonix architecture is built on three pillars:

  • Builder ‚Äì where the ABAP developer configures data sources, models screens, and adjusts behaviors.
  • Application (Viewer) ‚Äì a SAPUI5 renderer that interprets the extended vocabulary of annotations and presents the interface in a Fiori-like style, strictly following SAP guidelines.
  • Data Layer (CDS Views) ‚Äì the data layer modeled by the ABAP developer, also through the Builder, with pushdown, ensuring performance and consistency.

This design allows applications to be configured and rendered without the need to write JavaScript code. All logic for validation, determination, and execution remains in ABAP, preserving full control for the developer.

Difference Compared to Vibe-Coding

While other solutions focus on directly generating code, Tachyonix takes a different path:

  • We do not generate raw SAPUI5 code.
  • We generate structured annotations, which the Application interprets.
  • The developer keeps full control: still working with ABAP, CDS, classes, and FMs ‚Äî but never with unreadable AI-generated code.

This ensures:

  • Security of the result.
  • Predictability and adherence to SAP standards.
  • Continuous evolution of the app within the low-code platform.

The ABAP Developer as the Protagonist

SAP has been repositioning the ABAP developer at the center of extensibility in S/4HANA ‚Äî whether with new features in CDS or with Fiori Elements.

Tachyonix aligns with this movement, expanding the possibilities:

  • The ABAPer models data (VDMs).
  • Defines business rules (validations and determinations).
  • Configures screens in the Builder.
  • And the Application delivers the final Fiori-like experience.

In the end, the ABAP developer is the central gear:

  • They define the logic.
  • They control the runtime.
  • They ensure the app‚Äôs quality.

How the Architecture Works in Practice

  1. Start with Noam
    The user describes what they need directly to Noam, our AI assistant.
    Example: ‚ÄúI need a report of pending sales orders.‚Äù
  2. LLM + RAG + MCP
    The LLM, reinforced by a RAG mechanism, queries the Tachyonix Knowledge Graph and triggers tools registered in the MCP.
    Among them:
    • Package Tool ‚Üí identifies the correct ABAP package.
    • Data Source Tool ‚Üí suggests relevant CDS Views.
    • Field Retrieval Tool ‚Üí selects the appropriate fields.
    • Floorplan Tool ‚Üí recommends the most suitable Fiori layout.
    • KPI Selection Tool ‚Üí determines whether any KPI should be included in the application and specifies which one.
    • Additional Information Tool ‚Üí checks if complementary information is required for the application and incorporates it into the specification.
    • Action Button Tool ‚Üí defines which action buttons should be available in the application (e.g., Approve, Reject, Download), and links them to the appropriate ABAP logic or OData service.
  3. Conversion into Technical Specification
    With the MCP tools, the LLM converts the user‚Äôs natural language description into a consolidated technical specification.
    Then, it executes a dedicated tool that automatically creates CDS and persists annotations, enabling the Application to render the app later.
  4. Builder
    The ABAP developer uses the Tachyonix Builder to refine data sources, screens, and business rules related to frontend behavior, extending the newly generated application.
  5. Application
    The final application is not generated SAPUI5 code but a rendering via the Application, our viewer based on the extended vocabulary of frontend annotations.
    This ensures full compliance with SAP Fiori Guidelines, with security and predictability.
  6. Execution
    Business logic always runs in the ABAP Runtime, allowing the same developer to model:
    • Determinations
    • Validations
    • Action executions (ABAP class, function module, or OData service)

Architecture ‚Äì Overview

Conclusion

The Tachyonix architecture demonstrates that it is possible to bring together LLMs, RAG, MCP, low-code, and ABAP in a cohesive and productive flow.

The result is a model where delivery time drops from weeks to minutes, without sacrificing quality, security, or extensibility.

This approach does not replace the developer ‚Äî it empowers them.
And in a market where time and flexibility are competitive advantages, this is the new paradigm we are building.

ps: As an engineer, my passion is solving problems with code ‚Äî not writing long texts. So yes, I had a little help from a LLM to put these ideas into words. Think of it as using the right tool for the job: ABAP for apps, LLM for writing üòâ

entry.title: Half the World Away: A Geospatial Cautionary Tale
entry.content:
More than just a great Oasis song... this is a special case to watch out for when using HANA Geospatial features. This will be obvious to some, but here is something not particularly well documented, and I felt it was worth sharing.

 

So far but yet so close

I'd been playing around with HANA's Geospatial features. The challenge of the day was joining information from about 100,000 weather stations around the globe with nearby world cities. Part of this meant holding geo-coordinate information (i.e. Longitude and Latitude pairs) in columns with data type ST_POINT(4326) ‚Äì the WGS84 international standard, and using the ST_DISTANCE method to return the distance between them. Easy enough.
 
Soon, I noticed something strange ‚Äì although almost every city/station pair I had was behaving as expected, for a small handful I was getting some nonsensical results. Here are three such examples, along with a sensible result for Heidelberg (sorry SAP, Walldorf wasn‚Äôt in my table).

In the first example, my query was telling me that the nearest weather station to Auckland, New Zealand was in Moron de la Frontera... a Spanish Air Force Base‚Ä¶ on the other side of the globe. And it thought that the distance was exactly zero.

My immediate assumption was that I had done something stupid in my select statements, or had formatted some data wrong. Wanting to sanity check, I looked up the co-ordinates for each area.

  • Auckland: (174.764980799, -36.850013)
  • Spanish weather station: (-5.6, 37.1833 ).

A quick check on Google maps showed that this was indeed correct‚Ä¶ certainly both in their respective neighbourhoods.
So the co-ordinates seemed okay, and I even didn‚Äôt fall into the trap of getting the longitude/latitude order wrong.
(for the uninitiated, ST_POINT has these in (long,lat) order, the opposite of the more common way of presenting, which has (lat,lon). Something I find slightly annoying!)
Clearly something else was the matter...

Reproducing the issue

I thought it would be a good idea to try manually constructing the points, in case my SELECT or Calculation View logic was faulty. This also gave a distance of zero.

Now let‚Äôs move one of the points ever so slightly‚Ä¶.


Holy moly! Now we see the correct distance of about 20,000 km.

What happened? All we did was shift one of the points about 5 km ‚Äì you can see on the map it‚Äôs still in the same area.

So what‚Äôs going on? Is it because military bases are somehow restricted areas on the WGS84 standard?
Hmm‚Ä¶ probably not. Let‚Äôs try with another one of my pairs which did not work.

Here‚Äôs the city of Shenzhen, China (114.122123099, 22.55237051):

And a weather station in La Quiaca, a sleepy town on the Argentina/Bolivia border. (-65.6, -22.1):


Again, these points manually give a distance of zero.

Antipodes

At this point, I saw that the Wikipedia article for La Quiaca has an interesting sentence:

‚Äúan approximate antipode to Hong Kong‚Äù.

^see, I told you...

For those unfamiliar with Asian geography, let‚Äôs zoom out of Shenzhen and see where it is‚Ä¶

Aha... right next to Hong Kong. So we seem to have found the culprit.

In all cases, the pairs which were showing as zero distance were about as far away as it is possible to get on the other side of the globe.

In these extreme situations, distance formulae tend to break down a little. Let's dig further into this.

Vincenty's Formula

I believe the implementation of ST_DISTANCE in SAP HANA uses Vincenty‚Äôs Inverse Formula which you can read all about here.

The math may not mean much to you, but there is a little caveat at the end worth noting:

‚ÄúBetween two nearly antipodal points, the iterative formula may fail to converge‚Äù. In other words‚Ä¶ the equation fails for points on the opposite side of the globe.


That's exactly what happened here.

To further back this up, I found an online calculator with an explicit use of Vincenty‚Äôs Formulae here

It comes with a similar warning:

Vincenty‚Äôs inverse solution can fail on nearly antipodal points. Testing with Geographic¬≠Lib test data, I‚Äôve found this can happen with distances greater than 19,936 km, or within around 75 km of the antipodal point.

And sure enough, my co-ordinate pairs are throwing a 'Not a Number' error.

 

Final Words

So there you have it. If you are implementing any similar Geospatial projects, be sure to double-check and protect against antipodal failures.

In my case, I made a separate view to show the pairs giving exactly zero distance and manually confirmed the results.

I hope this saves someone a headache one day.
Good luck, and happy bug hunting!

-Elliott

entry.title: Re: SAP PM, how to move release orders 1-2 months early
entry.content:
Transaction IP30 allows you to schedule multiple maintenance plans in the background (batch job). If you adjust the start date / cycle date of the plans, IP30 will regenerate the calls and create new orders in bulk. This is the standard way to ‚Äúbring forward‚Äù calls without touching each one manually.

If the orders are already generated, you can use IW38 (Change PM Orders) with a selection variant. From there, you can mass‚Äëchange fields like Basic Start / Finish Dates and even Release status. This avoids opening each order individually.

entry.title: How SAP Intelligent Asset Management helps companies comply with ISO 55001
entry.content:
How SAP Intelligent Asset Management helps companies comply with ISO 55001

When assets are effectively managed, they don‚Äôt just operate ‚Äî they generate value. They are what keep the lights on in power plants, get trains to their destinations safely and on time, and help make factories more efficient and less wasteful. Today, organizations that truly unleash the power of their assets achieve efficiency as well as trust, resilience and a competitive edge.

Think of a pump at a water treatment plant. ISO 55000 tells the story of why that pump matters ‚Äî because without it, you‚Äôd be empty. ISO 55001 takes it a step further: It tells you how to monitor the asset‚Äôs condition, schedule maintenance before failure, and make decisions on whether to repair or replace it. The same is the case with any such critical infrastructure, whether it be power plant turbines or trains moving across a network.

This is precisely the vision for the ISO 55000 series of standards.  But to understand where we're headed, we must remember what came before and who started it all, and that's where eleven years ago, ISO 55000 provided the foundation as an answer to what and why of asset management. Its successor, ISO 55001, goes one step further and lays out the how: how to manage, monitor and improve asset management across the organization.

But before diving in, we need to ask ourselves the following question:

What is ISO 55001 and why is it important?

ISO 55001 is the international standard that tells organizations how to achieve real value from their assets in a structured, accountable manner. It‚Äôs not limited to maintenance routines, however: it links assets with business objectives, facilitates balancing risk and performance against cost and incorporates the discipline of continuous improvement into day-to-day operations.

In practice, this is most relevant for industries in which assets are not optional but mission critical. A lone turbine in a power plant, a safety valve in an oil refinery or a train traveling narrow throughway if any one of them fails, the results can be catastrophic: Safety is compromised, operations halt, and compliance is threatened. ISO 55001 is a framework that helps avoid those scenarios, so assets are instead operated as enablers of resilience and trust.

In Intelligent Asset Management at SAP, our Mission in the portfolio is to make the world‚Äôs assets work. ISO 55001 is no different: it provides a holistic, action-based approach that encourages the integration of governance, transparency and dependability throughout the lifecycle of assets.

From theory to practice

Think of a turbine at a power plant. With ISO 55001 you schedule hours of operation, monitor vibrations, plan preventive maintenance and determine when to repair or replace parts. You can measure efficiency, monitor risk and manage the full lifecycle so the turbine provides safe and reliable energy over its lifetime.

That may sound simple at first, you might think that ISO 55001 is easy and that any company could obtain certification but achieving compliance is more like running a Formula 1 team: success requires precision, coordination, and constant fine-tuning. Without that, most organizations will find ISO 55001 certification to be a serious challenge:

  • Fragmented data and disconnected departments
  • Limited traceability of investment and maintenance decisions
  • Difficulties in measuring and managing risk proactively
  • Manual processes that hinder auditing and compliance

Achieving ISO 55001 is not a quick fix. It demands organizational alignment and the right digital backbone to connect data, processes, and decisions across the enterprise.

How does SAP Intelligent Asset Management support customers in becoming ISO 55001 compliant?

Here are where advanced digital solutions like SAP Intelligent Asset Management make the difference. It's like flying first class on a transatlantic flight without having to worry about what they'll serve, making the journey as easy as possible.

But none of this can happen without a crew on board and that‚Äôs why ISO 55001 is not only about maintenance or asset management. It also covers financial planning, supply chain, operations, external providers, and data traceability. This is where other key pieces in SAP come into play on this flight, ensuring the best outcome:

  • SAP Cloud ERP‚Üí connects financial management and strategic planning with asset plans.
  • SAP S/4HANA Asset Management for Resource Scheduling ‚Üí ensures capacity based planning and scheduling across work centers and individuals
  • SAP Field Service Management (FSM) & Mobile Execution‚Üí ensures flawless scheduling & dispatching with external providers and contractors as well as work execution
  • SAP Business Network for Asset Collaboration‚Üí extends collaboration with partners and manufacturers.
  • SAP Asset Performance Management (APM) ‚Üí supports organizations in maximizing asset performance and reliability by integrating advanced analytics, IoT data, and condition monitoring with predictive maintenance and risk management, and is fully aligned with the new capabilities in ISO 55001:2024.
  • SAP Analytics Cloud & Embedded Analytics ‚Üí performance analytics and evaluation.

Together, these solutions make the path to ISO 55001:2024 not only more adaptable    but also lever for growth and value.

 
To demonstrate this alignment in a more formal manner, the table below shows how SAP solutions align with the ISO 55001 requirements across chapters 4 to 10.
 

ISO 55001 Requirements and SAP¬Æ Software

SAP¬Æ Software                                                                     Asset Management System Requirements (ISO 55001 Chapters 4‚Äì10)

Applicability of SAP solutions to ISO 55001 requirements (may vary based on the ISO 55000 maturity level of an organization and priority of asset management implementation topics)

4.context

5.Leadership

6.Planning

7.Support

8.Operations

9.Performance Evaluation

10.Improvement

 

Intelligent Asset Managment - Business Process and Scenarios

 

Portfolio and Project managment
SAP Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management XXXXXX 
SAP S/4HANA Project System (PS)  XXXX 
SAP Investment Management (IM)  XXXX 
Asset Network
SAP Business Network Asset CollaborationX XXXXX
SAP Asset Performance Management  XXXXX
SAP Ariba Sourcing  XX XX

 

Contingent Workforce and Services Procurement

 

Asset Operations and Maintenance
SAP Asset Performance Management  XXXXX
SAP S/4HANA Asset Management for resource scheduling  XXX  
Intelligent asset management  XXXXX
SAP Service and Asset Manager   XXXX

 

Let me show you how SAP puts this into practice:

1. Context and Leadership

ISO 55001 mandates that organizations define the scope of their asset management system, identify stakeholders, and assign clear leadership roles. With SAP Cloud ERP, companies gain a central system of record for all asset-related information, ensuring governance and accountability across the organization. Within the SAP Intelligent Asset Management portfolio, this internal governance can be extended further. For example, by using the SAP Business Network for Asset Collaboration to engage with external partners and suppliers in a controlled way, ensuring traceability and alignment across company boundaries when needed.

  • Update 2024 (section 4.5): Organizations must have a decision-making model which shows how each decision leads to value. SAP Intelligent Asset Management portfolio together with SAP Cloud ERP, provides the visibility and traceability to support this requirement.

2. Planning and Risk Management

ISO 55001 quality standard focuses on establishing objectives, plans, and a risk approach. SAP Intelligent Asset Management enables companies to design maintenance strategies based on proven methodologies, predictive analytics, and risk models, helping them prioritize investments and maintenance. It also connects end-to-end asset management processes with corporate objectives, portfolio and project management, and even shutdowns and turnarounds, ensuring alignment with the Strategic Asset Management Plan.

  • Update 2024 (section 6.2): The SAMP (Strategic Asset Management Plan) is now more prescriptive. It must include resources, capabilities, timeframes, contingencies, and financial links. SAP Intelligent Asset Management ensures this connection between strategy and execution. Within Intelligent Asset Management, SAP Cloud ERP manages complete asset master data (locations, documentation, maintenance plans, measuring points, partners, risks, warranty data), while SAP Asset Performance Management (APM) helps model risks and simulate investment strategies. This ensures strategic asset plans are connected directly with budgets and operational realities.
  • Update 2024 (section 6.1.2 / 6.1.3): Risks and opportunities must now be addressed separately with accurate identification, evaluation, and tracking. SAP APM provides structured models to identify, evaluate, and continuously monitor risks and opportunities, ensuring compliance with this requirement.

3. Support and Competence

ISO 55001 involves resources, competencies, and communication. SAP Intelligent Asset Management enables the capture and sharing of technical knowledge in a structured way‚Äîdigital twins, manuals, and manufacturer data‚Äîand ensures the flow of information between departments and external partners with SAP Business Network for Asset Management.

  • Update 2024 (section 7.6): A new section on Data & Information requires organizations to define attributes, quality, and sources for their data. SAP Cloud ERP provides a single source of truth.
  • Update 2024 (section 7.7): A new knowledge requirement stresses retaining and sharing know-how. SAP Business Network ensures institutional knowledge flows across partners and teams.

4. Operations and Change Management

ISO 55001 stands for control processes and change management. SAP Intelligent Asset Management digitizes maintenance and asset change workflows with full traceability. Collaboration with suppliers and contractors is evident and consistent, even with third-party services.

  • Update 2024 (section 8.2): Stronger control of planned changes across the full lifecycle is now required. SAP Intelligent Asset Management ensures traceability of change impacts.
  • Update 2024 (section 8.3): ‚ÄúOutsourcing‚Äù is recast as externally provided processes, products and services, thus making contractor management crucial. SAP Field Service Management (FSM) together with SAP Business Network for Asset Collaboration, enables effective supervision and collaboration with external service providers. For example, through Crowd Service.

5. Performance Evaluation

ISO 55001 involves the measurement, auditing, and review of the management system. SAP Intelligent Asset Management provides embedded KPIs, dashboards, and real-time reports for monitoring asset performance as well as focused Business Intelligence with SAP Analytics Cloud. The portfolio generates clear, audited evidence for certifications or internal audits.

  • Update 2024 (section 9.3): Management reviews must now include broader inputs (stakeholder changes, risk/opportunity effectiveness, decision outcomes) and deliver actionable outputs (resource decisions, plan adjustments). SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Intelligent Asset Management dashboards provide this evidence.

6. Continuous Improvement

Finally, ISO 55001 requires evidence of learning and improvement. SAP Intelligent Asset Management provides insights based on AI and machine learning and fuels these by closing the maintenance loop to optimize asset management strategies. Lessons learned and insights are shared within the organization as well as across the network, creating a virtuous cycle of continuous improvement. For more details, see Enterprise asset management | SAP Help Portal

  • Update 2024 (clause 10.3): The new concept of predictive actions goes beyond corrective/preventive. Organizations must anticipate failures, and decide when to maintain, renew, or retire assets. SAP APM‚Äôs predictive capabilities address exactly this.

As a strategic partner for excellence, SAP's ISO 55001 compliance isn't just about certification.

It's an opportunity to transform the way an organization manages its assets and what it achieves. And now with SAP Intelligent Asset Management, companies can not only make this task easier, giving them the opportunity to lead the future.

"In a future where assets are not an unnecessary evil, but a source of sustainable value."

SAP doesn't just help with ISO 55001... it lends a hand, helps, and supports companies so they don't have to walk down the administrative path, but rather take the leap toward excellence in asset management.

entry.title: BWZ CDM deployment ‚Äì custom library fails to load (library.js / library-preload.js not found)
entry.content:
Hi everyone, I'm glad to inaugurate this new subforum!


I‚Äôm deploying a multi-tenant application to SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition via Cloud Foundry using mta.yaml packaging and a cdm.json.

What works:

  • Deploying apps + custom library directly to CF ‚Üí apps launch fine, library loads.

What breaks:

  • Same apps deployed via CDM integration into BWZ.

  • Tiles appear in BWZ, but on launch I get errors related to the shared UI5 library:

Uncaught (in promise) ModuleError: failed to load 'argon/ui/lib/library.js' 
from /<siteId>/cap-ui.mylib/~<hash>/library.js: script load error

failed to load 'argon/ui/lib/library-preload.js' 
from /<siteId>/cap-ui.mylib/~<hash>/library-preload.js: script load error

The <siteId> / <hash> path rewriting seems to be BWZ-specific.

Environment:

  • UI5 runtime in BWZ: 1.140.0 (sap.ui.version in console).

  • manifest.json of my apps declares:

    "sap.ui5": {
  "dependencies": {
    "minUI5Version": "1.130.8",
    "libs": {
      "sap.m": {},
      "sap.ui.core": {},
      "argon.ui.lib": {}
    }
  }
}

Library definition in mta.yaml:

- name: mylib
  type: html5
  path: app/lib
  build-parameters:
    build-result: dist
    builder: custom
    commands:
      - npm install
      - npm run build:cf
    supported-platforms: []

Referenced in consuming app module:

requires:
  - name: myapp_html_repo_host
    parameters:
      content-target: true
  build-parameters:
    build-result: resources
    requires:
      - artifacts:
          - mylib.zip
        name: mylib
        target-path: resources/

What I don‚Äôt understand:

  • When deployed directly to CF, argon/ui/lib/library.js resolves fine.

  • When accessed via BWZ/CDM, the rewritten path breaks and the library never loads.

Questions:

  1. How should a custom UI5 library be packaged/referenced so BWZ resolves it correctly?

  2. Does BWZ/CDM require additional config (xs-app.json, initLibrary setup, preload format) for shared libraries?

  3. Is this a known limitation of BWZ content provider integration with custom UI5 libraries?

Tutorial followed for the destinations setup:
Developing HTML5 apps for cross-subaccount consumption

Is there a specific way I should rewrite the destinations that I missed? 

Thanks for your guidance, 

T.

entry.title: Re: Guidance Needed: Creating KPI Report with Graphs and...
entry.content:
Hello @Thanushree1999 

Thank you for reaching out.

Below are the practical ways to build KPIs using charts and KPI cards, along with guidance on when to use each option.

Create KPIs and Reports is ideal for KPI tiles with thresholds plus a quick drill-down (chart/table). Choose Generic Drilldown for a straightforward KPI to chart/table flow or use an Analytical List Page (ALP) if you want filters, tables, and charts on one screen. SAP Help Portal-Manage KPIs and Reports

Embedded SAC Story is ideal for creating rich dashboards that feature multiple graphs and KPI tiles on a single canvas. SAP Help Portal-Creating a Story

Data Analyser ‚Üí great for ad-hoc slice/dice on top of a query, quick tables and simple charts, less design. SAP Learning-Working with the embedded SAP Analytics Cloud

The step-by-step process applies to all three cases.

Model your data.

Create or reuse a CDS view (cube) and build a Custom Analytical Query with the required measures and dimensions. Test it in the Query preview.  SAP Help Portal-Extend and Integrate Your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Option A: KPI tile and drill down.

In Create KPIs and Reports, create a KPI ‚Üí select your query as data source ‚Üí define measure, aggregation, thresholds/targets ‚Üí Create Evaluation ‚Üí Create Tile. SAP Learning: Creating KPIs and Reports

Choose either Generic Drilldown (simple charts and tables) or ALP (facets, filters, charts, and table combined). Publish it to the launchpad. SAP Help Portal-Manage KPIs and Reports

Option B: KPI cards and comprehensive dashboard.

Open Create Story ‚Üí select the same analytical query ‚Üí add charts and KPI tiles ‚Üí save and publish the story/tile to the launchpad. SAP Help Portal: Creating a Story

Option C: Temporary or spontaneous approach

Open Data Analyser, point it to your analytical query, and build the pivot/visuals on the fly. Pin as a tile if needed. SAP Community-Embedded Analytics: SAP Analytics Cloud in SAP S/4HANA Cloud ‚Äì How to create a Data Analyser Report

Which one should you choose?

Need clean KPI tiles and a quick walkthrough for business users? ‚Üí Create KPIs, reports, and generic drilldowns.SAP Help Portal-Manage KPIs and Reports

Do you require a one-page dashboard featuring multiple charts and KPIs? ‚Üí Embedded SAC Story. SAP Help Portal-Embedded Stories

Need exploration rather than design? ‚Üí Data Analyser. SAP Learning-Working with the embedded SAP Analytics Cloud

Let me know if you need further information

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: How to do bulk upload for OData v4 service in 1 Batch...
entry.content:
@vishalsharma_19 is almost right, you just need to use $$updateGroupId:

const groupId = "bulkUpload";
var oOperation = oModel.bindList("/WarehouseData", null, null, null, {
      $$updateGroupId: groupId,
});
excelSheetsData.map(async (value) => {
       var payload = {
           IsActiveEntity: true,
           plant : value.plant,
           warehouse : value.warehouse,
           quantity : value.quantity
       };
       oOperation.create(payload);
       oModel.submitBatch(groupId)
});

 This way, each call to ODataListBinding#create is putting a POST into the group called "bulkUpload" and then the call to ODataModel#submitBatch is closing the current change set and opening a new one üôÇ If you do not specify $$updateGroupId, ODataListBinding#create defaults to the model's update group ID, which defaults to its group ID, which defaults to "$auto" - but then ODataModel#submitBatch is using the wrong group ID and cannot make a difference.
